Award.AwardTitle: Non-Linear Device Applications of Nano-Patterned Barium Strontium Titanate Thin Films

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective - The objective of this research is to investigate the non-linear properties of nano-scale active regions of barium strontium titanate (BST) thin films, their dependence upon deposition and patterning processes, and their manifestation in macro-scale observables including capacitance-voltage behavior. Important goals for this project include the development of non-linear computer-aided-design models and design techniques for BST circuits based on non-linear transmission line topologies. The approach is to use planar capacitor (varactor) structures, layered on a BST film, as the building block for more complex devices. The structures will be patterned using focused ion beam (FIB) milling to create nano-scale gaps.

Intellectual Merit - The varactors that will be developed have feature sizes on the same order of magnitude as the film's surface roughness - at this scale, the homogeneity of the film and resultant capacitance-voltage properties, switching speed and dielectric relaxation are not well understood. The exploitation of BST for microwave signal generation will require a thorough understanding of the non-linear properties and advancements in modeling methodologies.

Broader Impact - The devices that will be developed can have a great impact on society at large, as the functionality is integral to specialized systems such as military radar and many commercial telecommunications systems. Furthermore, the fundamental knowledge gained on non-linear behavior of BST will be useful to engineers and physicists working in related fields such as high-density memory. The PIs have a track-record of involving under-represented minorities in their research activities and will recruit female and minority students to perform this work.

Project Outcomes Report

 

Non-Linear Device Applications of Nano-Patterned Barium Strontium Titanate Thin Films

NSF Grant #ECS 0601536

University of South Florida

 

The primary objective of this project was to advance the current state of knowledge pertaining to nano-scale barium strontium titanate (BST) devices, particularly for RF/microwave applications. BST is a material system in which the permittivity can be changed with the application of an electromagnetic field, and therefore is of interest in the design of tunable or reconfigurable microwave systems. The development of fabrication techniques that enable the realization of devices with feature sizes on the order of 50 nanometers was a strong focus of the work. These small features are desirable in order to maximize the non-linear behavior of the devices in response to a radio frequency signal of practical amplitude.  A second major focus was placed on advanced measurement methods that enable the characterization of devices that can tune at nanosecond or sub-nanosecond speeds.

 

The two fabrication techniques that were studied are focused ion beam (FIB) milling and electron beam lithography (EBL). The substrate materials on which the BST films are deposited are highly insulating, in order to provide optimum microwave performance. However, this property of the substrates presents challenges to both of the nano-manufacturing methods. Using FIB, the material is bombarded with gallium ions to cut patterns; with EBL, a photosensitive polymer (photoresist) is bombarded with electrons to form patterns. In either case, a repulsive charge builds up as the ions or electrons impinge upon the surface of the insulating substrate and this diminishes the ability to focus the ion/electron beam, and consequently, the ability to create patterns with nano-scale features. Techniques were developed in this project to overcome this problem for both fabrication methods, and BST devices with feature sizes on the order of 50 nanometers were realized. Also, for the FIB method, a technique was developed to enable cutting these fine features through 0.5 to 1.0 microns into a stacked thin-film layer and stopping just above the BST layer. The fabrication techniques that have been studied are of general use in the nanotechnology and nano-manufacturing fields.

 

In order to study the speed at which the BST devices can be tuned, a parameter directly related to the use of the devices for non-linear applications such as pulse shaping, two measurement techniques were developed. One of these techniques relies on frequency-domain measurements, specifically the measurement of intermodulation products when a device is excited with two microwave signals at offset frequencies. The key to this technique is the ability to achieve a very high dynamic range, allowing small amplitude intermodulation products to be measured in the presence of much larger microwave signals.
